climbs.name: Yer Own Private Idaho
climbs.fa: early 1990s Bob Branscomb Ed DeLong Kristi Stouffer

content.description:
A very thin and a bit intimidating crux above the second bolt, very small hold slab climbing at its best (not for everyone). I rather like this climb but a lot of people not into slab climbing will not appreciate its demented nature.

I repeated this on 12/7/14 and found that the fire did not effect this route.
content.location: Just a little downhill and right of LL&L, on the left end of Fairfield East.

content.description: A fun romp up a thin seam, then face.  Features a cool little lieback around the 3rd bolt (crux).  Maybe the funnest route on this wall.  Well protected.
content.protection: 5 bolts, Fixx ring anchor, shares anchor with Realm of the Venusian Sex Pygmy.
content.location:
Route on the left side of the Sex God Wall, starting up a thin seam just right of an overhanging section (where Say Hello to Geronimo is located).

Sex God Wall is the (popular) group of 6 lower angle climbs on the right end of Fairfield East, as you first get to the cliff on the trail.

climbs.name: We All Lived on a Russian Submarine

content.description:
Start up a deceptively-tricky, right-leaning ramp before manteling onto the top of a pillar.  From there, continue up crimps and pockets through the headwall.

This climb is named in honor of a story told by Bob Branscomb about the origin of the upcycled titanium hangers that it features.
content.protection: 12 bolts to ring anchors stick clipping the first is recommended.
content.location: This climb takes the left side of the pillar that contains Big Bambu. Look for a right-trending, low-angle ramp.

content.description: A fun and sustained crimpy face between Apostrophe and Realm of the Pygmy Sex God.  Very well protected.  Rated 5.9 in the guidebook but I still think this is some sort of a sandbag rating.
content.location:
Apostrophe is the right most, under a small roof, route of the 6 Sex God Wall routes. Treats starts immediately left of Apostrophe and goes up and left, following the Fixx bolts. Sex God Wall is the set of (popular) lower angle climbs on the right side of Fairfield East, as you first get to the cliffs on the trail.

All the bolts on Treats are SS bolts, whereas the bolts on Apostrophe are (now) glue-ins.

content.description: Follow the obvious crack up the middle of the Pillar. Trickier than it looks.
content.protection: Glue in bolts to drop in anchor.
content.location: 4th route from the right side of the Pillar.  I’d describe it as the most prominent line on the Pillar, follow obvious crack.

content.description: Stalinism at its finest! Hard start gives way to a finger crack and jugs.  At 1/3 height, expect an all-day ledge, then continue up through sustained crimps and flakes to the anchors.  Good quality stone.
content.location: Directly in front of the first burned tree.  Look for the black finger crack in the dead center of the “pillar block.”  The first 2 bolts are fat glue-ins.

content.description:
Great line that burls up a slightly overhanging dihedral, then changes character completely with a testy face traverse.

Super fun - there are big flanges to pull on in the dihedral, and always decent stemming you can get going to keep any pump down.    But the moves are continuous and fun.  Then the face traverse is a real shift in tactics after all the stemming!

The book gave this route no stars, which I assume is because they never did this line?  At any rate I think it is one of the best 10a sport climbs I've ever done.   Do it if you are in the area!
content.location: Roughly in the middle of Fairfield East is a long tall route called Blind (11+).  Pretty obvious.  Just down the hill is a little buttress with a new red-tagged line on an arete.   In the shallow dihedral to the right of this is SMKW.

content.description: Start below the initial overhanging wall.  Clip first bolt and stem/face up and slightly right, then up to some good incuts and a side pull with the left hand to clip the third bolt.  Work a bit to the left and up into a lower angle area.  Pretty much straight up the very steep upper wall from there, the holds becoming very positive before the anchor.  The crux is the initial overhanging wall and getting past the third bolt, though the upper wall is probably 10a.
content.location: The next route left of West of Venus, on the left side of the Sex God Wall, right end of Fairfield East.  Look for bolts on the initial overhanging wall above an undercling.

climbs.name: Second Helping
climbs.fa: Bob Branscomb, Mark Vogel, Mike Steele

content.description: nice line, cruxes off the second and third bolts.  good stances to clip.  Perhaps the best climb in this section of cliff, for quality.
content.location: the straight up line between Physical Graffetti and Houses of the Holy on the left side of Fairfield Hill-East

climbs.name: Revenge of the Pygmy Sex God

content.description: Short and sweet, good feet and positive holds the whole way.  Bomber limestone and well protected.  An excellent novice lead or warm-up for the day.
content.location: inbetween Treats and Realm of the Venusian Sex Pygmies

content.description:
beautiful water streak left of "blind" starting in front of tree, "restless native" climbs up to first bolt then to the right to flakes and then back left at 3rd bolt and straight up.  the direct version has yet to be done!  originally equiipped by todd skinner.

named in honor of all the locals who seek and equip first ascents!!!
content.location: left of "the blind", in front of juniper tree

climbs.name: Realm of the Venusian Sex Pygmies

content.description: Low angle climbing with positive grips.  Heads up through steeper section and veers left to the anchors of West of Venus.  Bomber quality limestone the whole way.
content.protection: Glue ins and shares anchor with West of Venus
content.location: Right of West of Venus

content.description: Well-textured angular climbing leads to juggy finish.  This thought-provoking route will keep you on your toes, literally and figuratively.  Worthy of a try when you're out this way.
content.location: On the left side of Fairfield East, as of 2019 this is the 6th route from the end of the cliff.  It starts below 2 platforms reinforced with dimensional lumber and rebar.  Look for the dark colored rock before turning the corner into an alcove.

content.description: Crux down low, boulder problem/bulge, slab crux up higher.  Branscomb vision originally!
content.location: just to the left of "restless natives", on the other side of the tree, red streaked bulge down low

content.description: In 2011 Physical Graffiti was a heavily effected by fire due to the fact that it was directly over a tree.  In 2019 this climb was re-envisioned and re-cleaned.  This is now a good quality route with independent anchor and goes straight up.  This climb starts up ledgy terrain to pockets near the first bolt.  Leaving bolt one expect good pockets on vertical slab with not much in between for the hands.  Fairly sustained climbing with protection where you want it.  Expect more distance between bolts on easier terrain. Even though Physical Graffiti was not my favorite Zeppelin album this climb is highly recommended.
content.location: On the left side of fairfield east, just right of a dead juniper.  Below the “belay platforms” just up from the darker color rock.

climbs.name: Pap Smear
climbs.fa: FA Shannon Kelly, Equipped Jake Dickerson (November 2019)

content.description:
Fun short route on really great rock. Make a move right off the ground from a two finger pocket (crux) to a jug. From here, the difficulty eases up and you follow nice grippy pockets and flakes to the chains. More sustained pockets than most of the other routes at Fairfield.

The first ascentionist finished the route just in time to make it to her appointment...
content.location: Left route on the small buttress past the mini switchback at the left end of Fairfield East

content.description:
Face climb to small bulge to thin seam and beyond.

Long and proud.  After interviewing the Fairfield Hill regulars I am of the understanding Scott finished this line and has opened up this beautiful line for all.

Thanks for cleaning and opening this up.  Name and grade to follow when known. Likely at least 5.12 terrain.
content.location:
20 feet left of Blind.  Starts up a face to a small bulge. Then trends right up a seam and out of sight.

Left of Restless Natives between the burned trees.

content.description:
Climb the crack section of "Sorta Maybe Kinda Wild" until you reach bolt 5.  Instead of traversing right for the original finish (which shares an anchor with "Leon Trotsky's Hair"), continue up the crack and summit the pillar.  Take a solid rest here before going straight up through jugs and side-pulls.  Expect a tricky bulge crux before reaching the anchor.

A double length draw is nice to have on the bolt where it parts with SMKW to reduce rope drag.
content.location: Shares a start with "Sorta Maybe Kinda Wild," and continues upward through the headwall after the crack.  This climb begins in the dihedral right of a pillar in the middle of Fairfield East.

content.description: A hard start off the deck (high bolt protection)laying away into a corner on the right.  Go up this little corner, then left to the main crux, a thin move to a pocket and nice jug.  A hard crimping section above this to easier and fun ground.  Well protected and a lot of fun.
content.location: Just right and downhill from Presence on the left end of Fairfield East.

content.description: Begin on a series of jugs that lead to a good rest at the break.  Pull through good pockets and sidepulls up the headwall.  Fun, varied movement.
content.location: This is the last climb on the left side of the pillar (at the right end of Fairfield East).  It begins just left of the crack in the left side of the pillar.

content.description: Start in crack feature, which leads into low-angle face before pulling through a sequential bulge.  Steeper than it looks.
content.location: This is the first climb right of an obvious crack in the left side of the tower.  There is one other climb left of this on the pillar at the right side of Fairfield East.

content.description: prominent arete feature with chalk, technical and bouldery, equipped by b. branscomb
content.location: middle of the wall, left of dihedral

content.description: One of the less inspiring routes on the wall.  Surmount a ledge 6’ off the ground clip a high first bolt, look for a natural line up the face... finding very little you will likely end up traversing over the the manky crack to the left making difficult clips.  Goes right at the end through a small bulge at to to an communal anchor with Afterthought.
content.location: Right in the middle of Sex God Wall (right side of Fairfield East).  One of the least inspiring looking routes there.  First route right of Apostrophe which has glue-ins.  This route shares a chain anchor with Afterthought to its right.  2019 this is the only chain anchor at Fairfield East.  The bolts are 8’ right of a black/sharp crack like feature.

climbs.name: L. L. and L.
climbs.fa: Ed DeLong, Norm Thompson and Bob Branscomb 1995.

content.description: Pretty straightforward limestone slab. Thin start leads to bigger holds. It has recently been rebolted and recleaned and is worth climbing.
content.location: Leftmost route on Fairfield East main band.  Starts right of burned tree before cliff peters out. Updated 12/2019

content.description: This route is between SortaMaybeKindaWild and Che.  Starts below right end of a left slanting overlap.  Bouldery start goes to upper end of this overlap, thence straight up on thin crimping to easier area leading to the anchor shared with SortaMaybeKindaWild.  Interesting moves and crimpy at the cruxes which are: 1)getting established, 2)moving to the upper end of the overlap and 3) the main crux above a nice hold at end of said overlap.
content.location: Between SortaMaybeKindaWild and Che.

content.description: Start slightly uphill of the arete forming the right side of the buttress.  After a couple of bolts, proceed on the crest, ending on the left side of that crest near the end.  Balancey and delicate with the crux around the third and fourth bolts.
content.location: At the far right end of Fairfield East, following the right arete of the prominent buttress there.

content.description: This route shares an anchor with Presence to th right.  Houses of the Holy is the left route at 10b. Both are earlier Fairfield routes and have more adult runouts. Note the titanium Russian hangers. Very cool. The holds, like many earlier Fairfield routes, is a little rougher than many people like, but you have grip on these puppies like you can't believe! A good and sporty route.
content.location:
On the left side of Fairfield East. Houses is the next route downhill and right of Second Helping. Presence is the next route downhill, between Houses and Nimrod.

As of 2019 House of the Holy is the 5th climb from the left side of Fairfield East.  Below 2 platforms reinforced with dimensional lumber and rebar.

content.description:
Contender for best rock quality at Fairfield.  Climb grippy slopers, side pulls, and positive crimps leading to a engaging

arete.  Body positioning is as important as shear strength for this one.  Very cool climb be sure to check for fossils as you go.  Moderately

steep, morning sun afternoon shade.  A great climb for a warm day.
content.protection: Glue ins to clip and lower anchors.
content.location: Second climb from the shady far right side of the pillar.  Climb steep interesting rock trending left to arete.

content.description: Make big moves to big holds leading up to a bulge at top. Needs another brushing sesh.
content.location:
The first route on Fairfield east. Great new addition. In the shade for those warm sinks days.

Located just right of hieroglyphic .

content.description:
This climb starts up low-angle terrain with big holds that become smaller and trickier through a small bulge.  Finishes up heavily featured pods/flakes to anchor.

Enjoyable side pulling action can be found throughout the route.
content.location: On the pillar on the far right side of Fairfield East, this is the 3rd climb from the left.  It is located on a subtle prow following a system of flakes through a bulge.  Look for a huge left leaning jug as the first hold.

content.description: just to the left of "pistol whipped", on the other side of the tree, bouldery at bottom to slab climbing on black and tan stone, will clean up more

Starts on pretty solid rock with a stand up move into two underclings. Move through some good pockets and up to a flat edge. From here, there's several ways to negotiate the crimps above you and enter the layback flake. Pick your poison! Once on the layback flake, follow it up and left, don't fall on the big move, then climb fun holds/flakes to the anchor.

I really thought this thing was going to be hot garbage based on the rock quality, but it turned out to have pretty fun movement! Give er' a go!
content.protection: 6 bolts, rings. Well bolted. Stick clip the first. Hollow rock forced a mandatory stick clip.
content.location: Left of Leslies Arete, dead center of Fairfield East. Right of Stalin does Dallas.

content.description: Another nice piece of rock at the Sex God Wall.  Much like the rest of the SG wall tricky crimpy start, good quality pockets and crimps on low angle stone lead to a juggy top out.  Travels in a straight line to the anchors. Fairly tricky for 10a with a committing 3rd bolt.
content.protection: Tan SS hangers and bolts lead to a drop in anchor.
content.location: At Fairfield East the short clean right hand section before the pillar is know as the Sex God Wall.  This is the 2nd route from the left side of the SG Wall.  It’s quite short and leads to a communal anchor with Con’s right.

content.description: Short, low angle, big hold climbing from top to bottom.  Not a bad chunk of rock but there is not very much of it. Starts straight up then trends left to a communal anchor with Con’s left. Could be good first lead.
content.location: The most right possible route on the Sex God Wall before the pillar on right side of Fairfield East.  It’s sortive in a gully between the Sex God Wall and the Pillar. Share an anchor with Con’s left.

content.description: A very bouldery start all the way to the second bolt (stick clip the second bolt a nice option: it's a thin stance to clip from for this bolt). Very pumpy, thin, and crimpy.  A move off the second bolt snags a nice edge and from there life gets easier, though still not a giveaway.
content.location:
In the center of Fairfield East wall, goes up a reddish, sltly overhanging shallow corner, the second route right of MaybeSortaKindaWild.  Looks obviously bouldery.

The route between KindaWild and Che is Leon Trotsky's Hair (11c), a good route too.  The route to the right of Che is A Piolet for Leon (10d), also decent.

content.description: Nice line up the left side of a seam/arete.  Hardest part off the ground but the rest of the route is steep and fun moves.  Very, very well protected for us mere mortals.
content.protection: 6 clips will do it....VERY well protected.  Mussey hooks at anchor.
content.location: Follows the seam between Apostrophe and Afterthought Left.

content.description:
A vastly different route than it was during the 1989 FA, this climb weathered a major fire and has since been rebolted and re-cleaned.

The climb starts on a series of jug rails, before pulling onto a series of crimps and surmounting a small bulge. Once you are through the crux at half-height, there is still a good bit of pulling to do before the chains.
content.location: Between Bambu and Restless Natives.

content.description:
Start up a a left trending flake to a pocket rail traversing right passing bolt 3.  Then chase side pulls and jugs to the anchors out left.

The bolting is odd on this one.  Has glue-ins now likely rebolted post 2011 fire, but before 2018.
content.location: When heading out Fairfield east look for the stellar looking panel just right of that is a somewhat detached piller, this is the left most route on said pillar.  There is a burned tree 8’ to the right of the start.

climbs.name: The Art of Deception
climbs.fa: FA Matt Garvin, Equipped Taylor Spiegelberg, Jake Dickerson (November 2019)

content.description: Harder than it looks. The rock quality is quite good and littered with many pockets, but all of them are a little smaller than you want. There is a slight bulge halfway, making it tricky the whole way and surprisingly hard for how short it is. A contender for the shortest route in Lander? It was originally an old Bob Branscomb TR.
content.location: Left most bolted route in Fairfield East. It is the short, dark route just before the Meadow Rock TR's.

content.description: Sustained 5.10- crimping from the deck.  I wish it was about 20x longer, though.
content.location: Immediately right of Treats, on the Pygmy Sex God wall.  Somehow many people think the first bolt on Treats (a SS bolt) is the first clip, but no, start below the anchor on Apostrophe and crimp up to a higher (now a glue-in) bolt, then on up.

climbs.name: Afterthought
climbs.fa: Ed DeLong, completed 2009 by Bob Branscomb

content.description: Ed DeLong originally put in the anchor and then didn't do anything with it for years. I got sick of looking at it so I bolted it a while back. It seemed a real possibility that clipping the former 2nd bolt was so sketchy that you could hit the ground pulling in the rope to clip if you slipped off so in November 2021 I put in a bolt between the old 1st and 2nd bolts and another bolt between the old 2nd and 3rd bolts.  I also replaced the old chain anchor with new bolts and mussey hooks. Now it's not so heady getting up the thing. Crux between first and third bolts.
content.location: This route is right of Blue Condition, the right most of two bolt lines that go to an anchor with mussey hooks. Be sure to follow the right bolt line, as the left one is really poor. I have no idea who did it.

content.description: Thin and sharp (!) pockets & crimps. Eases after the 3rd bolt.
content.location: Right of Che

climbs.name: A Gift From Shannon
climbs.fa: FA Matt Garvin, Equipped Jake Dickerson (November 2019)

content.description:
Good bouldery route that follows side pulls and single pad pockets up a black streak on bullet stone. The route goes up a bulge, and is actually gently overhanging the whole way. There are two mini cruxes between bolts 1+2, and 3+4, but it is not over until you clip the chains. The rock is some of the best in Sinks, but it is unfortunately super short. Worth doing if you are in the area! Maybe 5.11d, who knows.

I believe the OG Fairfield hardman Bob Branscomb TR'd this nearly 30 years ago.
content.location: The right route on the small buttress at the left end of Fairfield East. Look for the obvious black streak
